text: Oliver Batali Albino (11 November 1935 – 4 January 2020), also sometimes referred to as Oliver Albino Batali, was a South Sudanese politician and civil servant. == Background == Oliver Albino was born on 11 November 1935 in Yei, South Sudan. He was a member of the Makaraka or Adio ethnic group in the Yei – Maridi area of Central Equatoria, closely related to the Azande ethnic group. p. 117, Scopas S. Poggo, "The First Sudanese Civil War", Palgrave MacMillan 2009 He completed secondary school in Rumbek and studied at the University of Khartoum. In the early 1960s he went in exile and joined the Anya-Nya resistance movement in Kenya. In 1965 Oliver Albino became part of the Sudan African National Union (SANU) in Uganda. In the late 1960s and early 1970s he was a teacher at a secondary school in Gulu, northern Uganda. Scopas S. Poggo, “Albino, Oliver Batali”, pp57 – 58 in Robert Kramer et al. “Historical Dictionary of the Sudan”, 4th edition, 2013, Scarecrow Press During that period he wrote his first book, The Sudan: a Southern Viewpoint (Oxford University Press, 1970). Oliver Albino was also a member of the Southern Sudan Liberation Movement’s delegation to the Addis Ababa peace talks of 1972. From 1975 – 1978 he was the Minister of Housing and Public Utilities in the Southern Sudan Regional Government led by Abel Alier. Mohamed Beshir Hamid, "Sudan: Attempts at National Reconciliation", in: African Contemporary Record, vol. 10, 1977 - 1978 For only two months in 1985, April - May, Oliver Albino was the Sudanese Minister of Labour in Khartoum. Kuyok Abol Kuyok, "South Sudan: The Notable Firsts", published in 2015 through AuthorHouse UK, Bloomington USA In 1996 – 1997 Oliver Albino was a fellow at the Weatherhead Center for International Affairs, Harvard University. In 2006 Oliver Albino published his second book "Democracy and power in the Sudan: How Decentralization Hurts". through AuthorHouse UK in Bloomington, USA. see e.g. https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss/134-2072629-5941366?url=search- alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords;=oliver+albino After the Independence of South Sudan in July 2011, Oliver Albino was appointed by President Salva Kiir as a member of the Council of States. http://fortuneofafrica.com/southsudan/representatives-of-the-former-council- of-states-of-the-republic-of-sudan-from-south-sudan-as-follows/ On 4 January 2020, Albino died in Augusta, Georgia from heart failure."Hot in Juba", Veteran Politician Batali Albino Dies https://hotinjuba.com/veteran- politician-batali-albino-dies/; cf.
